text:
SEGMENTATION OF A SEISMIC SECTION 
USING IMAGE PROCESSING AND ARTIFICIAL 
INTELLIGENCE TECHNIQUES

P. L. LovE* 
., 
Exploration Research, Gulf Research & Development Co., P.O. Box 37048, Houston, TX 77236, U.S.A.

M. SIMAAN 
Interactive Computing Laboratory, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, 
Pittsburgh, PA 15261, U.S.A.

Abstract--Methods for segmenting stacked seismic data into zones of common signal character based on 
texture analysis are described. Their performance is demonstrated on a line of seismic data from the Gulf of 
Mexico that had been manually segmented. Two segmentation methods are described. The first is a template 
matching scheme that matches previously selected data templates with a block of pixels. The second uses 
statistics determined by examining the run-length of seismic reflection events. The run-length method is 
extended, through a decision process called the RESOLVER, to incorporate heuristic rules to influence the 
segmentation. A comparison is made between the automatic segmentations of the section and a manual 
interpretation.

Texture analysis 
Run-length 
Artificial intelligence 
Template matching 
Seismic sections 
Image processing

Two methods commonly used in the texture analysis of 
images are adapted to the segmentation of stacked 
seismic sections into zones of common signal charac- 
ter. The first of these matches a set of selected texture 
patterns with a block of pixels. The second method 
uses statistics generated from the run-length of re- 
flectors to segment the image. This latter method is 
then extended to take into account geologic and 
structural information in the section that a human 
interpreter usually uses to guide and constrain a 
manual segmentation. The algorithm which applies 
these constraint rules is similar to rule-based search 
methods commonly used in artificial intelligence 
applications. 
Large zones with common seismic signal character- 
istics can be recognized on stacked seismic data from 
the Gulf of Mexico. Figure I shows a manual segment- 
ation of a portion of a Gulf of Mexico seismic line into 
four character zones. It is believed that these regions 
contain some geologic information. In particular, 
large-scale tectonic events have effects on image tex- 
ture. These events include salt diapirs, shale ridges and 
regions of intense faulting. Further examination of the 
geologic meaning of large-scale character changes

The template matching approach has received con- 
siderable attention in the image processing literature 
as a tool for scene understanding and texture 
analysis. (2-4) If the signal character and hence texture 
can be captured in one or more templates extracted 
from each region in the image, it would then be 
possible to classify every pixel in the section by 
* Present address: ALCOA Technical Center, ALCOA 
Center, PA 15069, U.S.A. 
409

requires the segmentation of large regional areas 
containing many miles of seismic data. The manual 
interpretation of such areas is difficult to perform in a 
regionally consistent manner. This motivates the de- 
velopment of an automatic analysis method. 
These character zones are larger spatially than a 
typical segmentation of a seismic section based on 
seismic stratigraphy. (I) Seismic stratigraphy asserts 
that zones of common seismic signal character are 
related to the geologic environment in which their 
constituent sediments were deposited. Different depo- 
sitionai environments lead to differences in reflector 
geometry, lateral variability in reflector strength and 
continuity. Automatic seismic stratigraphy is a more 
ambitious image processing problem than the pro- 
blem discussed in this paper. This work might be 
considered a preliminary investigation of such a 
technique with more limited goals.
;'ig. I. A piece of stacked seismic section from the Gulf of Mexico. A manual interpretation of four large regions of common signal characler is shown by the dark lines,

matching its local texture, as characterized by the 
seismic data in its neighborhood, to these templates. In 
this section we propose a least-squares approach for 
template matching where the neighborhood around 
the pixel to be classified is expressed as a linear 
combination of the templates. The expansion coeffi- 
cients are simply calculated by applying a template- 
dependent filter (or mask) on the data• They are then 
used, along with a measure function, to arrive at a 
classification of the pixel in question. 
Let W~, i = 1 .... , N be a set of N templates (selected 
by an expert from an already interpreted section) 
representing the various textures present in the seismic 
section. More than one template can be chosen from a 
given region. Each template is chosen as an archtype 
for a particular expression of texture• The set of 
templates for a given region is intended to capture the 
range of variability of texture in that region. It is also 
important that templates from one region have low 
correlation with templates from the other regions• This 
seemed to be generally true and did not greatly 
influence the final template choice. Templates were 
chosen by trial and error to maximize the number of 
correct classifications in each region• 
Each template is assumed to be an n × m matrix of 
data pixels. It is also assumed that the section is 
composed of M distinct regions and that the templates 
are indexed such that I~ represents the set of indices ofi 
which correspond to region k. Thus the templates { W:

templates).

Classification can now be done based on any of the 
following measures. 
(a) Largest projection norm. x is classified as belong- 
ing to region k* if l[,~. [I >/ II Xk II for k --- 1 ..... M.

(b) Smallest error norm. x is classified as belonging 
to region k* if ][ X - "~k" II ~< II X - gk It for k = 1 ..... 
M. 
(c) Smallest projection angle, x is classified as be- 
longing to region k* if 0 k. ~< 0~ for k = I ..... M.

In all these cases, in order to control the effectiveness 
of the classification, a threshold level can be imposed in 
addition to the measure requirements. For instance, 
the inequalities II g~. II t> ~, II X - gk. II ~</~ or 0~' _< 7 
may be imposed in addition to the above measures 
respectively in order for the pixel to be classified. If the 
threshold requirement is not met, the pixel is left 
unclassified. In practice it has been found that the 
smallest projection angle is more effective than the 
other measures. 
As a final point, note that because a seismic section

tends to have layered reflections, it may be possible 
that two pixels x, and x 2 in the same region, belonging 
to the same trace, but slightly separated in time, could 
give drastically different expansion coefficients a~. This 
is an indication that the masks F~ in (4) can be sensitive 
to slight shifts in time on the section. In order to 
overcome this problem, blocks of pixels are classified 
instead of individual pixels, This is done by classifying 
every pixel in the block using the projection-angle 
measure, and then assigning the entire block to the 
region which receives the largest number of pixel 
classifications. This sliding of the template over the 
block of data is equivalent to cross-correlation. A very 
fast algorithm to implement this technique can be 
developed by multiplying the template, and a panel of 
data consisting of a large number of blocks, in the 
frequency domain. 
Before discussing an application of this method to a 
specific real data example, we will discuss another 
segmentation method based on the concept of run- 
length.

Among the wide variety of features used for texture 
analysis, gray-level run length has been used in only a 
few applications. ~6 7j A gray-level run is defined as a 
coilinearly connected set of pixels all having the same 
gray tone. The length of the run is the number of pixels 
in the run. Previous applications have extracted run 
lengths by making one-dimensional scans across an 
image at a few angles. Statistics calculated from these 
run lengths have been used to segment or identify the 
image. 
Particular characteristics of seismic sections must be 
considered in the design of a run-length algorithm for 
seismic data. First, runs on a seismic section corre- 
spond to reflections many of which tend to be nearly 
horizontal. The algorithm used here finds run lengths 
along reflection events for a range of angles centered 
on zero degrees. Second, a seismic section is com- 
plicated by the wide range of positive and negative 
pixel values. To simplify the image, amplitude values 
larger than a positive threshold are replaced by 'ones' 
and values less than the threshold are replaced by 
'zeros'. The result is a binary gray-tone level image 
where the 'ones' correspond to the dark streaks 
(positive reflections) in the section. Our run-length 
algorithm operates on this simplified image. 
The amplitude threshold was chosen by examining 
binary images for a range of thresholds. The threshold 
should be low enough so that the image retains texture 
character but high enough to insure that the noise does 
not create artificial runs. A value somewhat close to the 
mean of the histogram of amplitude values was used in 
our numerical tests. The results of the algorithm are 
insensitive to changes of + 30% in this value. It is 
expected that a single value could be used for seismic 
lines of similar acquisition and processing.

Because of the large amount of data in a regional 
seismic survey it is essential that the run-length 
algorithm can be stated in an efficient vector-oriented 
form. To explain the algorithm we begin by assuming 
that every run in the image is horizontal. The al- 
gorithm is composed of a 'look-forward' and a 'look- 
backward' loop. If Rr(i) is a component of a vector of 
run lengths at the Kth horizontal location indexed by 
the vertical pixel value i, and if Tr(i) is an element of the 
vector of pixel values at that location, then the look- 
forward loop is defined by:
Re = TK + (Tr ° Tr + l) + (TK • TK + I • TK + :) +

where N is the number of horizontal locations in the 
image and the operation • represents element by 
element multiplication. Similarly, the look-backward 
loop is
R~. = T r + (TK• TK_I) + (TK• Tr_ ~ • Tr_2) +

In (8) and (9), the vertical index i has been suppressed. 
The final run-length result is the sum of the two loops. 
That is, Rr(i) = 
Re(i) + 
R~.(i) is the number of 
contiguous 'ones' on either side of this location. 
To generalize this algorithm to allow non- 
horizontal reflectors it is necessary to define a vector 
operation (,) as shown in Fig. 2. When positive signals 
overlap in time the operation outputs a positive signal 
for the duration of the overlap of both signals. When 
they do not overlap, the operation corresponds to the 
'and' operation in Boolean algebra. Computationally 
the (,) operation is the successive addition of shifts and 
multiplies with all non-zero output samples norma- 
lized to one. The shifts are done to account for sloping 
reflectors over a range of slope (dip). The quantity 
T 1 • (T l • T2)is then equal to those pixels of T~ which 
correspond to pixels of T2 over a range of reflector dip. 
In our numerical examples we have used a range of dip 
of _+45 °. We translate this into the appropriate 
apparent dip on the seismic image. The look-forward 
loop is now modified to:

In order to apply the run-length algorithm to 
segmen! the seismic section, the pix¢l values Tx{i) are 
replaced by an array of run lengths Ra(i) of the same 
size. Statistics are then calculated over blocks of this 
run-length array. Although it is possible to use many 
statistics, it was found that the RMS-avvrage-run- 
length and the avvrage-vertical-spacing-bctwcen-runs 
were the most useful for classification. These arc 
intuitively natural variables since they are a measure of 
the lateral continuity and dominant frequency of the 
reflectors. Based on these statistics, segmentation can 
be accomplished by establishing threshold cuts as- 
sociated with each of the various character regions on 
a two-dimensional scatter plot of these two statistics.

In this section, we consider an example of a real 
seismic section which is segmented manually by an 
interpreter, and automatically using the template 
matching and run-length algorithms. 
The Gulf of Mexico stacked seismic section shown 
in Fig. 1 consists of 750 vertical time samples at 8 msec 
sampling period and 1200 horizontal distance samples 
at i 10 fcct sampling period. The manual interpretation 
of this section identifies four regions labeled 1-4 as 
having different signal character. For instance, region 
I is characterized by having short horizontal reflectors 
with varying degrees of vertical spacing. Regions 2 and

3 both have long continuous reflectors, with region 2 
having, on the average, a smaller vertical spacing 
between them. Region 4, on the other hand, is charac- 
terized by chaotic reflections and line noise with 
variable orientations. 
Geologically, the top of region 4 represents roughly 
the base-of-reflectors in the Gulf of Mexico. It includes 
shale ridges and salt. domes. The progression from 
region 1 to 2 to 3 is influenced by the general 
compaction of sediments with depth. 
The results of applying the template-matching al- 
gorithm to the section shown in Fig. I is displayed in 
Fig. 3. Three templates per region were chosen from 
the section for the analysis. The square box symbol (F-]) 
indicates region 1, the cross ( x ) region 2, the triangle 
(A) region 3. The lines drawn on Fig. 3 are the 
segrnentation boundaries from the manual interpret- 
ation shown on Fig. 1. The algorithm finds that most of 
region 4 does not correlate well with templates from 
any region and thus it is easily classified. That is, region 
4 corresponds in almost all cases to the unclassified 
part of the image. There are some isolated unclassified 
blocks which do not correspond to region 4. 
In general, this algorithm tends to confuse structural 
dip with signal character. Thus a large part of region 2 
is classified as region 3. Similarly the classification of 
region I is very sporadic, probably due to the varia- 
bility of the signal across the region. 
Figures 4-6 show the results of applying thc run- 
length algorithm. Figure 4 shows the binary image 
obtained from Fig. 1 by applying a threshold on the 
data. Clearly this image has preserved the horizontal 
run-length characteristics of the original image. The 
run-length statistics as applied to Fig. 4 are shown on 
Fi& 5 along with straight-line boundaries used to 
classify the data. These boundaries have been chosen 
manually by examining where points, corresponding 
to blocks from a given region of the image, cluster in 
this two dimensional parameter space. These same 
boundaries would be used to classify other seismic

short run lengths ( < 5 or so horizontal locations) and a 
large vertical spacing between runs ( > 10 samples). The 
algorithm tends to do most poorly on region 3 where 
it mixes in some obviously poor choices for classifi- 
cations. The overall result is however much closer to the 
manual interpretation than the template-matching 
algorithm.

The main disadvantage of the two methods dis- 
cussed earlier is that they do not take advantage of the 
structural and geologic properties of the seismic 
section. Both methods treat the section as an image not 
influenced by the order of geologic events which 
generally characterize the entire region from which the 
section is only a piece. Therefore, as an extension to 
either of the two methods discussed earlier, an intelli- 
gent 'decision-process' called the RESOLVER is added 
(Fig. 7). The RESOLVER attempts to add some 
artificial intelligence to the classification process by 
modelling heuristic constraints that a human interpre- 
ter would use while segmenting a seismic section. An 
interpreter, for instance, is aware that regions to be 
segmented are contiguous areas that are com- 
posed ofseverai classification blocks. His classification 
of a particular block is strongly influenced by the 
potential classification of neighboring blocks. An 
interpreter might also have geologic information re- 
lated to the depositional sequence of the various 
regions in the section. All this information is indepen- 
dent of whatever image texture he sees and may even 
prejudice what he thinks he sees. It is clearly indepen- 
dent of our statistical assessment of texture. 
Heuristic information, like the above, can be im- 
plemented as rules which alter the degree-of- 
membership, a measure of to what extent a particular 
block of pixels belongs to a certain region. As an 
example, the following four rules can be used in a 
RESOLVER which can be applied to the data shown 
in Fig. 2. 
Rule I. The depth prejudice rule. It is unlikely that a

block below 2 s should be classified as region 1. It is 
unlikely that a block above 1 s should be classified as 
region 3. This rule is related to the effect of sediment 
compaction on seismic signal character. 
Rule 2. The sequence rule. In a vertical column of 
blocks, if the block directly above a block in question is 
classified as region 2, then it is unlikely that the block 
in question belongs to region 1. The same applies for 
region 2 with respect to region 3. 
Rule 3. Region 4 shape rule. Region 4 is a solid figure 
instead of a layer. That is, it is composed of salt domes 
and shale ridges. It is improbable that a block is in 
region 4 if the blocks above and below that block are 
classified other than 4. This rule is related to the 
expected topology of the image. That is, a diapir is 
expected to have nearly vertical sides. 
Rule 4. The neighbors rule. If among the nearest eight 
neighbors around a block in question the majority 
(/> 4) are assigned to a particular region, then it is very 
likely that the block in question belongs to the same 
region. 
We will now illustrate how these rules can be 
implemented in a RESOLVER which takes as input a 
seismic section which has been processed by the run- 
length algorithm. 
As a first step, the run-length algorithm discussed 
above is modified to yield for each block of data pixels 
a vector D containing the degrees-of-membership (on 
a scale from 0 to 1) of that block to all regions in the 
section. The ith entry di in the vector, corresponds to 
the degree-of-membership of the block in region i. The 
degr~-of-membership in a region is calculated from 
the position of the (R MS-run-length, average-spacing) 
point for a block of pixeis on the plot shown in Fig. 5. 
In each of the four regions, a small rectangular area in 
the RMS-run-length, average-spacing plane (Fig. 5) is 
assumed to contain points which are correctly classi- 
fied (membership = l) as belonging to that region. 
Points outside a larger rectangular area are assumed 
to have zero membership in that region. A linear 
interpolation (see Fig. 8) between the boundaries of 
these areas based on the position of the point is used to 
calculate the degree-of-membership of the point in the 
region. The vector D = (dl, d:, da, d4) corresponding to 
the degrees-of-membership of each block of pixels in

Fig. 8. Degree of membership in region i. Scale decreasing 
outwards from I to 0.

Fig. 9. The outcome of a particular search done by the 
RESOLVER.

each of the four regions is then passed to the 
RESOLVER decision algorithm. 
The RESOLVER algorithm is a LISP program 
which does a depth-first search guided by a hill- 
climbing method. The outcome of a particular search 
is depicted in Fig. 9. The initial state is a vector D o of 
degrees-of-membership for this block and each of the 
classes. The initial node is expanded by application of 
each of the four heuristic rules. The subsequent states 
are compared with a goal state which requires one 
block to have a degree-of-membership above a mini- 
mum threshold and all other degrees-of-membership 
below a different lower threshold. If none of the states 
meets this goal the search continues by expanding the 
node which is closest to it. Note that only the rules that 
have not been applied to that point in the search are 
used to expand to the next depth. 
At each level in the search the rule which changes the 
state so as to bring it 'closest' to the goal state is the one 
used in the expansion. This almost always ensures that 
rules that are most appropriate for a given block,

In the above formula, d~ = max {dj, d 2, d 3, d~.} and 
the di's are the remaining three values, dmi~ is the upper 
threshold which requires that d~ must be made larger 
than it and dml, is the lower threshold which requires 
that the remaining di's must be made smaller than it. 
Clearly, in the above formula, if it should happen that 
for a given state, dx is bigger than dN, or that some or 
all of the d/s are less than dmi,, then those differences 
are not included in the calculation of the distance d. 
In this algorithm there are two sets of arbitrary 
constants. The first are the changes in degrees-of- 
memberships that a particular rule produces. The 
second are the thresholds, d,,,x and d,,~,, which deter- 
mine whether a goal state has been achieved. Modify- 
ing the degree-of-membership changes allows for 
relative weighting between the rules. If the thresholds 
are made more stringent relative to these changes, the 
RESOLVER is forced to apply more rules before 
reaching the goal state. 
Applying the above to the Gulf of Mexico example 
discussed earlier, we used equal changes of 0.2 in the 
degrees-of-membership due to the application of a 
rule, a maximum threshold of d,,., = 0.5 for a given 
region, and a minimum threshold for all others ofd H 
= 0.3. Our aim was to maximize the number of rules 
applied but limit the number of blocks left unclassified.

With the above value, it was found that on the average 
more than 2 rules are applied for each block before a 
decision by the RESOLVER is reached. Only a few 
blocks are left unclassified. Figure 10 shows the results 
of the classification using the Resolver described 
above. When compared to Fig. 6, the results are not 
dramatically different. Significant improvement, how- 
ever, can be seen in region 3 where the RESOLVER 
has eliminated many of the erroneous classifications 
that were obtained by the run-length algorithm only.

Several results emerge from this investigation of 
automatic segmentation of stacked seismic data. 
It is clear that while neighborhoods of pixels in a 
particular region may share many textural features 
there can also be considerable variability, This is 
evident in region 1 of the example. Note further that 
dip variations in region 2 easily dominated other 
effects like reflector spacing, and may lead to good 
correlations with templates from region 3. It seems 
necessary then to carefully choose texture measures 
which are strongly influenced only by common charac- 
teristics in a region. It is as important to choose what 
features of a region to ignore (e.g. dip) as it is which 
ones to include. This ability to ignore certain features is 
one of the strengths of the human interpreter which is 
not often easy to duplicate in a numerical algorithm. 
The algorithm based on run-length seems more 
powerful than the template-matching scheme for this 
data. This is probably because of the inherent sensitiv- 
ity of data templates to any variability in the data. 
Both methods discussed have a spatial resolution 
problem. In each case, blocks of data about a pixel 
comprise the basic analysis unit. The size of these 
blocks is affected by several factors. Textural infor- 
mation is enhanced by making the blocks longer in the 
vertical direction. Increased size horizontally tends to 
repeat the same reflectors thus adding only statistical 
weight to the textural measure. Larger vertical length 
tends to smear across region boundaries creating 
blocks with intermediary statistics. This last effect is

About ihe Author--PATRICK L. LOvE received his B.S. in Physics from St. John Fisher College, Rochester, 
NY, in 1970. He received his M.S. in Physics and Ph.D. in Astrophysics from Washington University, St. 
Louis, MO, in 1972 and 1977, respectively. From 1977 through 1984 he has been employed by Gulf Research 
& Development Company, where he has been involved in research in the processing and interpretation of 
reflection seismic data. Presently he is with ALCOA Technical Center, where he is involved in research on 
applications of artificial intelligence. He is a member of SEG, AAAI and IEEE.

About the Author--MARW^N SIMA^N received a B.S. degree (with distinction) from the American University 
of Beirut, Lebanon, an M.Sc. degree from the University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, and a Ph.D. degree 
from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, Illinois, all in Electrical Engineering, in 1968, 1970 and 
1972, respectively. 
During the summers of 1967 and 1972 he held summer positions with English Electric Leo Marconi 
Computers Ltd., U.K., and with Bell Laboratories, Columbus, OH, respectively. From 1972 to 1974 he was a 
postdoctoral Research Associate and then a Visiting Assistant Professor with the Coordinated Science 
Laboratory and the Department of Electrical Engineering at the University of Illinois. From 1974 to 1975 he 
was a Research Engineer with Shell Development Company in Houston, TX. Since 1976 he has been on the 
faculty of the University of Pittsburgh, where he is presently Professor of Electrical Engineering. Since 1979 
he has also been a Consultant for Gulf Research & Development Company in Pittsburgh, PA. His research

responsible for some of the lack of clustering in the 
run-length scatter plot shown in Fig. 5. 
The incorporation of heuristic segmentation rules 
via a search procedure, as implemented by the 
RESOLVER program is promising. Further improve- 
ments may occur if the rules involved larger spatial 
elements of the section. It might be possible to have 
rules that effect boundary drawing between large 
numbers of blocks in the section. Another limitation is 
the late stage in the processing sequence at which the" 
rules are applied. Such rules might be more powerful if 
used earlier to select different statistical measures or to 
choose the position of analysis blocks. 
In summary, a run-length algorithm augmented 
with heuristic segmentation rules yields acceptable 
performance for the segmentation of Gulf of Mexico 
stacked seismic data into four large zones of common 
signal character. Several areas of improvement have 
also been suggested by this investigation.
